item.title: Bose’s Latest ANC Wireless Headphones Hits Record Low, New QuietComfort Ultra Bluetooth Headphones (2nd Gen) Is Now Cheaper Than AirPods Max
item.content:encoded:
A quick word-association exercise will usually produce the word “Bose” when the question is “luxury headphones.” In terms of performance and especially active noise cancellation, that’s absolutely true. But in terms of price, even Bose’s newest models are more accessible than you might think, and never more accessible than right now thanks to this $50-off Amazon deal on the QuietComfort Ultra 2 wireless headphones.

The QC Ultra 2s dropped just this past October at $450, but lately Amazon and other retailers have quietly slashed the price deep into deal hunter territory. That means this $400 Amazon deal represents savings on months-old Bose headphones that would make even the most hardened tech shopper blink and the most devoted audiophile reach for their wallet.

See at Amazon

Serious Sound, Serious Deal

Here’s the wild part: Despite its premium positioning and outstanding , this deal pushes the QC Ultra 2s below the cost of some older Bose QuietComfort models (yeah, the ones that aren’t even “Ultra”). So if you were on the fence about spending bigger on flagship-level noise cancellation, this Amazon deal makes the argument a whole lot easier.

Bose took their stellar original QuietComfort Ultra headphones and made several significant upgrades to create the QuietComfort Ultra 2s. This latest model delivers Bose’s very best adaptive noise cancellation performance, with AI-based background noise suppression and Wind Block tech for listening in windy conditions. Bose added two new sound modes – Immersion and Cinema — along with support for wired lossless listening via audio or USB-C cables. The Cinema mode is a high-performing spatial setting which balances the overall audio in favor of dialogue, ideal for streaming and podcasts.

Truly Premium

Even the physical look of the Bose QuietComfort Ultra 2 headphones is a step up from the originals, with more premium materials, polished metal yokes, and an overall sleeker and more modern look. The over-ear comfort level of the Ultra 2s is a step up from the already-pleasing original Ultras, and the battery life has been upgraded from 24 hours to 30. But it’s the active noise cancellation that Bose really leans into, and if you’re still recovering from holiday travel that involved overcrowded planes or trains stuffed with noisy commuters, you know the real value of a pair of world-class noise-cancelling headphones.

Bose’s QuietComfort Ultra 2 wireless headphones pair easily with any Bluetooth device — Apple, Google, Android, and any properly equipped smart TV, for starters — and the Bluetooth Core 5.4 connection is strong and steady. This somewhat unexpected Amazon sale bringing the QC Ultra 2 headphones down to $400 so soon after their release is the best way for you to experience true Bose sound without breaking the bank.

item.title: Peak Dev Explains The Completely Bonkers Psychology Behind Game Prices
item.content:encoded:
Game pricing is more all over the place than it’s ever been as developers explore the top and low ends of the spectrum, as well as everywhere in-between. And that’s before seasonal sales, subscription services, and monthly giveaways. Indie games in particular used to have to fight to prove they were worth the price of admission in the eyes of gamers used to big blockbuster spectacles produced on AAA budgets. But the psychology underlying those perceptions isn’t as clearcut as some might think, according to one of the developers of 2025’s top-selling “friendslop” climbing sim Peak.

The game launched last June at a discounted sale price of $5. That was $3 below what would be it’s “normal” price of $8. Co-creator Nick Kaman recently explained the logic behind the maneuver to Game File. “We had this joke of, like, how much is a game really?” he said. “In a player’s mind, what does it mean to spend five bucks? Well, that’s five bucks. But six bucks? Well, that’s still five bucks. Four bucks is also kind of five bucks.”

He continued, “Three bucks is two bucks. And two bucks is basically free. So we’ve got these tiers: You know, twelve bucks… that’s ten bucks. But thirteen bucks is fifteen bucks. And we found that eight bucks is still five bucks. It doesn’t become ten bucks. Seven ninety nine, that’s five bucks, right? So, eight bucks going to five bucks is the biggest differential we could find in pricing, so we found it very optimal.”

The developers of Peak didn’t randomly pick $8 out of a hat. That was the price of Content Warning, another hit in the multiplayer virality sim genre. But the overall logic lines up with something game designer and Suspicious Developments studio founder Tom Francis recently wrote about indie game pricing. His take was part of a four-point advice guide for new developers based on his 15 years of experience making games like Heat Signature and Tactical Breach Wizards.

Steam indie game pricing is a “solved problem”

According to Francis, game sales are a function of three things: 1) how many people come to the Steam Page, 2) how much the Steam page makes them want to buy it, and 3) how much it costs. “We just ask people how much they think the game should cost, and every time we’ve gone with the price most people chose, and every time they’ve sold great and reviewed great,” he explained.

He pushed back against the older conventional wisdom that meeting player expectations rather than setting them would lead indie game prices in a race to the bottom. “Among the many genres and models that didn’t exist back then is the occasional janky/silly/ugly game charging $5 to encourage a kind of ‘fuck it, why not’ good will, and blowing up if it lands right with streamers,” he wrote. “That might bring the median price down, but it’s not a sign that people will no longer pay $20 for an indie game.”

You can see this philosophy in action with the recent release of Rising Front, a pretty ugly-looking, very rudimentary WWI and Revolutionary War battle sim FPS (complimentary). Its 1.0 launch on Steam on January 9 was accompanied by an influx of fairly positive reviews. It’s normally priced at $15 but is currently on sale for just $12. According to Kaman, that’s actually $10. Maybe after reading the Peak developer’s comments, Rising Front‘s creators will lower it to $8.

item.title: Google Pixel 9a Drops to All-Time Low to Compete With Samsung Galaxy S25 Deals, Now the Cheapest Gemini-Powered Smartphone
item.content:encoded:
The Google Pixel 9a Android smartphone features a 6.3-inch Actua display, a Google Tensor G4 processor, built-in Gemini AI capabilities, and an IP68-rated body. It also comes with 8 GB of RAM and 128 GB of storage, making for a seamless experience for users who want to stream, browse, and switch between applications continuously. Additionally, there is an Adaptive Battery designed to provide more than 30 hours of usage time, a durable frame, and seven years of OS and security updates, ensuring users feel they have a powerful phone for an extended period.

Amazon has discounted the Google Pixel 9a from its typical price of $499 to $399, giving you a 20% savings of $100.

See at Amazon

A powerful smartphone perfect for casual and advanced users

The 6.3-inch display on the Google Pixel 9a provides enough space to show both your apps and videos comfortably, yet it’s still small enough to hold comfortably in your hand. The display also supports adaptive refresh rates, reaching a maximum of 120Hz when swiping quickly, and lowering back to conserve battery life when viewing static content.

The Google Pixel 9a is powered by the Tensor G4 processor, with 8 GB of memory and 128 GB of internal storage. You can easily keep multiple applications open and switch between social media platforms, maps, and video content simultaneously while running AI-based features in the background, without delays or freezes. Gemini was integrated to provide summaries of web pages, compose simple responses, or retrieve information from your Google Apps using voice commands. The Pixel UI and continued software support for Android 16 mean you can expect frequent new features and security patches for many years to come.

Google has developed a camera app for the Google Pixel 9a that uses AI-based algorithms to convert quick snapshots into higher-quality photographs with minimal effort on your part. You can take portraits, low-light pictures, and quick-action shots, and use the “Best Take” feature along with “Add Me” to ensure the correct positioning of subjects’ faces within a single frame.

The Google Pixel 9a’s battery life, protection, and call features are designed to let you use the device heavily without having to check the remaining battery life frequently. The Adaptive Battery is intended to last longer than 30 hours, and when activated, the Extreme Battery Saver will further extend the battery life. The phone also carries an IP68 rating, allowing it to withstand dust, water spills, and brief submersion, and includes various safety measures to protect your data against theft, vehicle accidents, phishing scams, and other potential threats. For $399 on sale, down from the regular retail price of $499, you can enjoy a bright 6.3-inch screen, advanced AI features, dependable camera systems, and extended software support in a well-balanced mobile device.

They’re a lot different fromtraditional in-ear or over-the-ear headphones, as they rest on the bony ridges of your cheek bones. But they’re very well worth trying out if you never have, especially since they’re on sale right now.

Using bone conduction technology to deliver sound to your skull, your ears remain open to traffic, conversations, pedestrians, etc., allowing you to maintain situational awareness while enjoying your music. The SHOKZ OpenRun Pro-Bone Conduction Headphones are perfect for those that run, bike, walk at night, or simply do not enjoy wearing traditional in-ear or over-the-ear headphones.

The SHOKZ OpenRun Pro-Bone Conduction Headphones are currently available on Amazon for $109.95 (down from $179.95), which is a discount of $70 or 39% off.

See at Amazon

Bone conduction headphones that sound fantastic

The headphones’ lightweight design provides a full wrap-around frame that sits lightly on the back of your head, so there’s no pressure inside your ears and no clamping force on your ears. That makes them ideal for extended periods of running, hiking, or working and listening to music/podcasts without discomfort in your ears. In addition, they can be used in conjunction with sunglasses, hats, and helmets, thereby minimizing clutter on your head.

Because your ears remain open, you can hear traffic, bicyclists, announcements, coworkers, etc., while listening to music or taking calls. Situational awareness can be particularly important if you run on high-traffic roads, walk in more dangerous areas, or exercise at the gym, so you can see what’s going on around you.

You can listen to hours of music on a single charge. Therefore, you can utilize the SHOKZ OpenRun Pro-Bone Conduction Headphones from a morning workout to a series of errands or work-related tasks before needing to recharge. Recharge times are short and simple, and you will be able to quickly resume using the headphones.

In terms of functionality, the SHOKZ OpenRun Pro-Bone Conduction Headphones can handle calls and playback controls easily. The integrated microphone clearly transmits your voice during phone/video calls. Onboard buttons enable you to play, pause, skip tracks, and adjust volume without having to access your phone. Bluetooth connectivity is fast and reliable, so once you have paired the headphones with your device, you will have seamless connectivity from the moment you activate the headphones.

The SHOKZ OpenRun Pro-Bone Conduction Headphones were designed for active lifestyles. They are water/sweat-resistant, so you do not need to treat them as fragile items during demanding workouts or on extremely hot days. Additionally, the secure fit ensures that the headphones remain securely positioned on your head regardless of how intense your workout becomes.

If you’re looking for affordable but unique headphones that are different than most of the others on the market, these are the ones you’ll want to choose. Be sure to get yours now before they’re no longer on sale. And get ready to answer questions about them since they’re so unique.

item.title: Jackery Is Offloading the Explorer 300 Portable Power Station at an All-Time Low, Priced Like Small Power Banks
item.content:encoded:
As the calendar flips to a brand-new year and the rush of holiday shopping fades into the background, many people find themselves holding onto gift cards or leftover holiday cash, wondering what worthwhile purchase to make next. If you’re looking to invest in something practical, versatile, and genuinely useful year-round, a portable power station is an excellent place to start. One standout option right now is the Jackery Explorer 300, a compact yet capable power solution that is now part of a limited-time Amazon discount.

Normally priced at $259, the Jackery Explorer 300 is currently available for just $179, marking a 31% price drop and a solid $80 in savings. For anyone who’s been on the fence about adding a portable power station to their gear collection, this deal might just push you onto the buying side.

See at Amazon

A portable power station is one of those items you might not realize you need until you really need it. Whether you’re planning outdoor adventures or simply want peace of mind at home, something like the the Jackery Explorer 300 is a must in both scenarios. It’s ideal for camping trips, road travel, tailgating, or even backyard gatherings where access to outlets is limited. At the same time, it’s a smart emergency backup to keep in your car or garage for unexpected power outages or roadside situations.

Weighing just 7.1 pounds, the Explorer 300 is super lightweight for the power it delivers. The integrated top handle makes it easy to grab and go, whether you’re heading into the wilderness or pulling it out during a blackout. Despite its compact size, it packs enough energy to keep essential devices running when you need them most.

Universal Connectivity

The Jackery Explorer 300 can power up to six devices at once, making it a great option for families or group trips. It includes two AC outlets for larger electronics, a 60W Power Delivery USB-C port for fast-charging modern laptops and phones, a USB 3.0 fast-charge port, a standard USB-A port, and a DC car port. This variety ensures that nearly any device you own can be powered or recharged without hassle.

In terms of performance, the Explorer 300 delivers reliable results. On a full charge, it can run a mini cooler or a television for approximately 4.5 hours. It can recharge smaller devices multiple times over, including about 31 phone charges, four laptop charges, 15 camera recharges, or around five and a half drone recharges.

Recharging the power station itself is quick and convenient. Using a standard wall outlet or the USB-C Power Delivery port with an AC adapter, it can reach 80% capacity in just two hours. For those who prefer renewable energy or off-grid use, it’s also compatible with solar charging when paired with panels like the Jackery SolarSaga 100 (sold separately).

Safety and reliability is important. The Jackery Explorer 300 uses pure sine wave technology, ensuring a stable and clean power supply that protects sensitive electronics.

At $179 for a limited time, the Jackery Explorer 300 is a pretty sweet deal. Whether for outdoor adventures, emergency preparedness, or everyday convenience, it’s a smart way to start the new year with a purchase you’ll actually use.
